author: rahulkaushik999

title: Twisted LMxUU Bearing, Parameterized
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
NOTE: I have not actually printed any of these yet, but I wanted to share the design.

This is another printable LMxUU-style linear bearing, with a twist (literally). Instead of simple straight inner grooves, these twist to wrap around the rod. This may help to distribute forces (and lubrication) more evenly.

I have included examples for the most commonly used sizes. The default versions are 'light duty', suitable for vertical applications such as a delta-style printer. There are also 'heavy duty' (HD) versions with at least 50% more contact area to handle larger side loading typical in horizontal applications.

If you load the .scad file into OpenSCAD, you can see the settings I used to generate the examples above. Hint: Highlight the section you want to use and press [Shift]+[Ctrl]+D to remove the "//" comment marks.

comments.text:
Is it a gun barrel ? Trying to shoot the smooth rod accurately ?
Why do you think polymer linear bearings have straight grooves ?
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
it's supposedly to distribute the weight evenly across the entire bearing and to relieve the stress on the bottom grooves which would otherwise usually exclusively take the bulk of the pressure.
Can anyone confirm or deny if it affects performance though?
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
I don't know why the "designer" did that, may be just to look cool ?
Fact is, linear polymer have straight grooves to allow dirt and grime to get out. A sprial groove would force it back to be squeezed between bearing surfaces !
comments.author: sh0tybumbati

comments.text: For me, this was primarily a thought experiment. I challenged myself to make a specific design using a specific tool and learned much along the way.
comments.author: MKSA

title: BTL-B Y-wing starfighter (x-wing) Clone wars ver 0.25

description.text:
there are 2 printable versions. 1 is in 2 halves and the other complete depending on how you want to print and the final ship should be 61mmx32mm making it perfect to use with x-wing

update 03.03.2017 if you are having problems slicing please use the fixed version

update 06.03.2017 the newest version (ver0-85) is a L70mm x W30mm x H8mm model which isn't 100% to scale (for x-wing) but was much easier to work with (instead of 7.1, 28.85 and 6,23)
both models used the same basis model so should end up the same size when finished.

I found a CC 3d image on the www that I use as the bases of this Ship here is a link to the original data

I got tired of breaking battery straps in a crash on my R5LX and R5X. I designed a plate that
will take the angle away from the plates. The battery strap is now pulling against a flat surface.

I have printed in both TPU and PLA. TPU flexed too much when tightening the battery strap. I settled on printing them all in PLA. They both weigh 3g when complete.

description.text:
This is a 58mm filter holder I did for Gopro Hero 5 (without case).
Seeing as I haven't found anything yet I used MMWORKS idea and re-did all to fit hero5. Only used the 58mm sizes with a calliper. Everything else was made from scratch with illustrator.
I still don't know how to make it a screwing type so it fits by pressure.

It's my first time posting anything as I'm new to this, so any advise would be wellcomed.

Anet A8

Doesn't Matter

Yes

0.1

25 or above

I've got some issues with my printer (supports too hard to remove) but maybe it won't need them.
If you print it please share thoughts, pics and settings

that's the next thing I'll try to do. I'm looking for a way to make the inner threads so that you can fix the filter to use a CPL because this is too tight and depending on the filter it won't rotate (it is even hard to remove a normal one, but that's good because it doesn't fall off)
When I manage to improve it I'll update it.

comments.text: Ahh! I just looked it up and apparently filter extension rings are a thing! You could keep it how it is and pressure fit/glue one of these 58mm-58mm extension rings(very cheap by the way) into it for an actual filter to screw into! You could fine tune it and make the dimensions where it is flush once the extension ring is installed and so any filter would screw into it like normal!

author: Carlikus

print_settings.Notes:: You will probably need supports when you print the blade, but other than that they should not be necessary.

description.text:
This was me taking a stab (hehe) at designing something from scratch. It's not meant to be some kind of historic reproduction obviously but really a chance for me to see what I could do with Tinkercad. This is admitted very much a novice effort.

You will notice that the hilt in the STL file is different from the one in the picture. A coworker pointed out to me that the ends of the guard were upside down so I fixed them.

The scabbard is a bit clunky and at some point when I make version 2.0 I'll try to make it a little more elegant.

At any rate, it actually functions as a decent letter opener.

Printer:

DaVinci Jr.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

You will probably need supports when you print the blade, but other than that they should not be necessary.
You may find it necessary to trim down the part of the blade that fits into the hilt. Mine was a pretty tight fit.
Designed using Tinkercad.

remixed_from.author: 0110-M-P
remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi 3, Pi 2, and Model B+ case with VESA mounts and more

title: Raspberry Pi 2 Pi 3 Terminal Block Case

description.text:
0110-M-P's Raspberry Pi Case is now my goto source as it is designed so perfectly. This is a modified version of that.

Recently I have been working on an enclosure for my 3D printer and Octoprint. I have been integrating several different sensors into the Octoprint Raspberry Pi using a terminal block shield which you can get HERE. This makes things so simple and clean for connecting wires to your Pi.

I will warn you, this is a snug fit. Typically I design things to slide in effortlessly, but didn't want gaps visible around the terminal blocks; it will slide in though. It is also worth mentioning that I don't know the tolerances on the terminal block boards. I only purchased one board which the openings was designed around.

The feet and bracket in the picture are not part of this remix. They are part of a mounting bracket that allows you to quickly pop on/off anything with a 75mm VESA mount. You can view that HERE.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Top-> Made with Maker Geeks Nuclear Green 2.85mm PLA
Bottom-> Made with Made Solid Silver 2.85mm PLA

description.text:
I made a 5 turn helical antenna a while back that has been fairly popular. The original antenna is found here; http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:858112
Since then I have gotten several requests for a longer 7 turned version, so I thought I would take a stab at it. The older antenna was a remix of another design, but the new one is made from scratch.

I have wondered why the base reflector of helical antennas are one wavelength in diameter. Would a wider base make any difference? A while back I found Serbian university research papers that described practical tests conducted with different reflector designs for helical antennas. It turned out that a bowl reflector with a 2.5 wavelength diameter is vastly superior to the standard 1 wavelength disc. I have designed such a reflector. If you decide to use it, you could attach aluminium or copper foil to the surface, or use the design as a template for a reflector in copper or brass mesh.
There are further papers that suggests use of a cylindrical reflector. It seems promising, since it would be easy to realize in many materials, but I have not made any design for it:
http://home.etf.rs/~milanilic/publications/papers/AWPL-2006_01624449.pdf
http://home.etf.rs/~milanilic/publications/papers/Olcan-Eucap06.pdf

The design criteria are the same as for the 5-turn version: I wanted an antenna that offered full protection for the wire, was compact and easy to print and did not require using glue for assembly. My design consists of two items that are held together with a single screw. It can simply not get any simpler.

There are both left and right hand polarized versions of the former and the wire holder. Make sure to print the version you need.

Build Instructions

  • The reflectors should be seen mainly as templates. Print one and use it to produce a reflector out of PCB material or copper. If you use a PCB, the copper surface must be turned forward, i.e. be the side that the wire holder is mounted to.
  • Insert the antenna connector in the out-most hole of the reflector and cut the wire 5-6 mm above the surface.
  • Fan out the outer isolation of the antenna wire and solder it to the reflector. There is a picture of this step in the process to make it easy to see what I mean.
  • Paint or lacquer the reflector to make it fingerprint proof. This step is purely aesthetic and may be skipped.
  • Print the holder and the former.
  • Use the wire former to create a wire spiral.
  • Thread the wire on the holder and cut it to length in place.
  • Use an M3 screw and nut to fasten the holder to the reflector.
  • The last step is soldering the main wire and the antenna center wire together. To achieve the best results possible the connection to the antenna wire is very important. The main wire should be in parallel with the reflector board for the last 4 mm of it´s length. This section of the wire should be located 2 mm from the surface of the reflector (thanks to Dave855 for the information)
Designed in FreeCAD, the competent and free although somewhat hard to master 3D design program.

comments.text: Looks like the optimal reflector in the paper is the truncated cone, not the cylinder. Am I wrong?
comments.author: noXi89

comments.text:
No, you are absolutely right.

title: Tiny Whoop - Balanced Charging Plate 1s to Xs
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This item is a lipo 1s to Xs (with X from 2 to 6) balanced charging plate. It permits to charge lipo 1s in series with a balanced plug (commonly used JST-XH) with a lipo charger. A servo jumper permits to choose the number of lipo in series by placing it at the right place.

Be careful : it exists different connector for 1s lipo. I used the micro JST-PH 2.0mm connector. Generally, stock 1s lipos for tiny whoop are selled with JST 1.25mm connector. The Jst 1.25mm may fit with some hot glue. You also can swap your former 1.25 connector to a 2.0 of each of your lipo. The choice of 2.0mm connectors comes from the intensity deliverable what may increase the power of your quadcopter.
The wiring image shows the back of the top plate. Solderings are quite tiny, as your quadcopter in fact.

• 6S balance cable for lipo battery (JST-XH)
  • XT60 connector plug (female)
  • 2x M3-8 screws
  • Micro JST-PH 2.0mm connectors
  • Pin header 3 row (x5)
  • Wires

print_settings.Notes:: For the funnel, a brim or raft may be useful, as the funnel’s own brim isn’t too wide.

description.text:
A funnel where the main parameters can be changed. You either get a special stand with it or not. When you want to use light things, like just a few tea leaves, pick the simple stand. The tripod stand should be much sturdier, but i haven’t printed one yet.

I wanted a funnel with a rather low throat ratio, if that is the term, to fill paper tea filters. The tea leaves always jam in the necks of supermarket funnels.

Set the sizes in the customizer. Then, when done, switch from “preview” to “render” and click “create thing”. You should get two STLS, one empty when you switch to the funnel only style.

Printer:

CTC Bizer

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 µm

Infill:

20 %

Notes:

For the funnel, a brim or raft may be useful, as the funnel’s own brim isn’t too wide.

You need one or three sharpened standard sized pencils as the main support elements. Stick them sharp-end-first into the base, tear or saw of the erasers, if your pencils came with them, and stick the funnel on top of the pencils. The length of the pencils determines the height you get for your receptacle. Use a pencil sharpener to lower your funnel until you’ve reached the right height. Make sure all pencils have the same length.

• I re-uploaded the SCAD file with three main options: no stand, simple stand, as seen in the photos, and as a new variant a tripod stand.
  • Fixed the connection between the funnel’s pencil holder and the vertical holder plate
  • Fixed the connection between the stand plate and the vertical bit (twice). Also uploaded slightly larger STLs with the fixes.
  • Made the handle on the standless funnel bigger, added a support for that.
  • Changed the width of the conical part. Should fix a problem where there was a gap between the perimeters that reduced the strength.
  • Partial re-design. Preview and render, three STLs. Tip angle of 0° now means flat, (that was called 90° before).

This part is also available at github. Older versions are still available there.

• When you want to funnel foodstuffs, you should probably use PLA, food grade PLA when you are concerned. Or maybe PETG.
  • You should probably clean your nozzle once, to get rid of mineral oil and other residues.
  • When you use an oiler, use a suitable oil. Maybe a vegetable oil or something like Ballistol oil.
  • The funnelled material comes into contact with the printed parts for only a short time, so it should not be effected by the plastic too much. Especially when you use dry stuff.

These two articles shed some more light on the issue:

  • 10 things you need to know about 3D printing & food safety
  • Food Safe Video

In the end, it is up to you. I can take no responsibility.

author: matthewlaberge

description.text:
• http://youtu.be/2RIBSVsIbjE
  • http://flickr.com/photos/geekubator/sets/72157629825289523/
    • Some of you may remember how practical the removable build platform of the Cupcake CNC was! The aim of the project is to make a build platform (here demonstrated on a MakerBot Thing-O-Matic) which is easy to remove from the 3D printer and facilitates the removal of the 3D printed part by the pealing principle. The base of the platform is made out of a 3 mm thick aluminium plate. It has twelve 10 mm holes in which 2.5 mm thick high-strength neodymium magnets are placed. The plate is screwed onto the heated build platform of the 3D printer. The removable part of the build platform is made out of 0.6 mm flexible steel sheet. It is strong enough to resist any warping from the stress of the 3D printed plastic model, but flexible enough to be held down firmly by the magnets and to bend and be peeled of from the printed plastic model. Normally 3D printed models with large bottom surfaces are difficult to be removed from a stiff build plate, resulting in high stress on the 3D printers build plate structure when one tries to bend it off. In other cases one tends to use sharp blades wedged between the model and the build plate, which tends to damage the heat resistant Kapton tape. The flexibility of this thin, removable build plate makes it much easier to remove the 3D printed plastic model without damaging the Kapton surface. This prototype was developed and made with the good help of MakerBot operator http://www.thingiverse.com/barspin

Cut a 3 mm aluminium plate to the size of your 3D printer's build platform
Drill some holes through it
Press/glue some high-strength neodymium magnets into the holes
Cut a thin magnetic steel sheet to the same size as the build plate
Cover it with Kapton tape
Mount the aluminium plate to your heated build platform
Place the steel sheet on the alu plate with magnets
3D print anything you want
Easily remove the thin plate and insert a new empty one into the 3D printer to print new stuff right away!
Wait some moments for the removed 3D print to cool down
Easily peel off the steel sheet from your plastic 3D print Enjoy! :) Check out video and images as follows:
  • http://youtu.be/2RIBSVsIbjE
  • http://www.flickr.com/photos/geekubator/sets/72157629825289523/

comments.text: How did you secure the magnets?
comments.author: MakeItPrint

comments.text: Genius Idea, sir.
comments.author: EliteNetworks

comments.text: What happens when magnets are placed near a ferrous compound is that the magnetic fields that are induced inside that compound have a high tendency to "gather" around the edges. So there is no or very little magnetic field coming out of the flat face of the plate, and if there is the entire side is one pole so there is no fluctuation of magnetic field across the build plate. Any force that the head would experience is not only tiny but uniform, and therefore would have no effect on the operation of the printer.
comments.author: grabercars

comments.text: Do you have any noticeable head/print instability while the head is anywhere near a magnet on the first few layers?
comments.author: in4mer

comments.text: No. :) There is no noticeable instability of the print head above the magnets. In fact all the magnetism "flows" through the thin steel plate. On other words there is no noticeable magnetic attraction above the sheet.
comments.author: in4mer

comments.text: Any particular pattern of magnets that you recommend? I originally worried about the Curie Temperature (for those that do not know, the temperature at which a magnet loses its magnetism) but Neodymium's is over 300, so well below what anyone's build platform or even material should be at.

title: Protective foot for chair
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a foot to fit on the leg of a welded metal chair. We had previously used a slip-on plastic/teflon foot but could not find them anywhere, so we decided to make our own!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

None

Notes:

We printed ours using Spool3D transparent PLA on a Prusa i3 Mk2.

Installation

I designed this to snap on and not fall off if the chair is lifted off the floor. As such, it may be difficult to push onto some of the metal bases; some of them may have a slight flare-out on the bottom that will prevent the foot from slipping on. This happened about 20% of the time. We solved this by pushing the chair down into the foot when the chair is upright on the floor.

The foot may seat fully once you sit on the chair.

The old, worn foot. The protective foot removed. The new protective foot.
Designed with Fusion360.

comments.author: nablabla

comments.text:
Made one, and it served it’s purpose right with the small spools that came with the printer itself. But when I hung a 1 kg spool from it, the weight warped my Z-axis, and the holder itself flexed a lot more than comfortable. It did not break, but did deform elastically to the point where I thought the roll would skip over the edge.
So now I decided to go with the TUSH concept instead, and take the load off my Z column.

comments.text: I agree with ahowie111 - this thing is not strong enough to hold up a 1kg spool.  In addition, it is about 20 mm longer than it needs to be, which means that the torque on the base is more than it needs to be.  I used a 40% infill and PLA.

author: alberich_

description.text:
A printable pegboard. 8 inches on 2/3/4/8 inches.

Created especially to match pegs created with the Pegstr customization wizard: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:537516

Pegs are 1 inch from each other (measuring from the center of the hole) and has a diameter of 1/4 inch (actually a bit more, because when I printed it with 1/4 inch I couldn't push pegs into it).
I've added a second set of holes that are also 1 inch of each other for more dynamic structure (which also saves on filament).

I printed 2 of the "pegboard4-8on4.stl" + 8 risers, 8 m6 screws and 8 m6 nuts to connect each board by it-self.

It's also possible to connect several pegboards using my pegboards connector (and that way you can connect to a wall with just 4 screws): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2145096

After that I started printing all the pegs that matches my tools (and I designed the missing ones, like a logitech c170 webcam holder - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2145043).

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50

Notes:

You can add a raft if you're have wrapping issues on big square objects (just like this). I printed without a raft.
The infill is for your consideration, I think it can be anywhere from 20 percent to 100 (but on real need for such a high infill) - the more infill, the stronger the pegboard.
Designed in Tinkercad

inscription = Dona Tamba

A Neti pot is a traditional South Asian tool for irrigating and clearing the sinuses. A company called NeilMed has introduced a widely-available Neti pot product, and also a variant I prefer that works by squeezing rather than pouring, which they call the Sinus Rinse. This thing is fantastic whenever you have a cold or allergies that cause your sinuses to be congested. I've created a simple rack for storing the two parts of the NeilMed Sinus Rinse (the bottle and the nozzle). Much better than leaving the thing lying around on your counter or shoved in a drawer, this rack keeps it out of the way and allows it to dry between uses; since it's in sight, it also provides a subtle reminder to actually use it. The back is sized to fit 3M double-sided tape for easy mounting on tile or glass.

Print the rack and clean up as necessary.  It's a single piece.  Tolerances are generous so it should work right off the printer.  
Put a strip of double-sided foam mounting tape along the back, and mount it in an appropriate spot.  Since a small amount of water will drip off as the thing dries, it's smart to find a place where drips will not cause problems, e.g., over a counter, a sink, a plant, a towel rack or wastebasket.  
Have fun!

M5 bolts, 25mm long, hold everything together.

author: Kangri

description.text:
• Added 3 tags
    It is not a remix
    I fixed my citations

Mystery artifact created by Lyndsey May

My clues
  1. This coin was made in 1945.
  2. The president played a significant role in signing a joint declaration with a British Prime Minister.
  3. This declaration was important because it set out a vision for the postwar world.

Can you tell… that by the shape of the face on the coin which president it is?

Additional information

The Object:
A coin with the president’s face on it during a significant time.

Details about the Object:
The coin represents a significant time after a war. The president did so many significant things during this time that there was a coin with his head on side of it. It has his name written around the side of it. The Atlantic Charter was a joint declaration released by the president and Winston Churchill, it was a set out vision for postwar world.

President:
President Franklin D. Roosevelt. In office from 1933-1945 served for 4 terms in office. Democratic Party.

Presidential Role:
Chief Diplomat/ Chief Policy maker.

Presidential Act:
Signed a joint declaration with Winston Churchill for postwar world and British war aims. Franklin D. Roosevelt is the only president to have served 4 terms in office. The Atlantic Charter was issued on August 14th, 1941, it issued Allied goals for the postwar world. It impacted the future for the U.S. with global issues. It allowed people to feel more positive about their country and the steps they’re taking to more forward from war.

Impact on America:
This is important to us and our country because it set out a plan for the future U.S. This declaration meant a lot to people because they know they could feel good about the steps moving forward. This declaration was to get people to start positively thinking about their country post-war world. I chose this president because I knew he had served a long time as president and he played many different roles. He made many big decisions that impacted this country to this day.

Works Cited
Office of the Historian, Bureau of Public Affairs. (n.d.). The Atlantic Conference and Charter 1941. U.S. Department of State. Retrieved from https://history.state.gov/milestones/1937-1945/atlantic-conf

Atlantic Charter. (2017, February 23). Retrieved February 26, 2017, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlantic_Charter

Franklin D. Roosevelt. (2017, February 22). Retrieved February 26, 2017, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt

Atlantic Charter - Franklin D Roosevelt Silver Medal | Misc. Tokens, Medals & Exonumia. (n.d.). Retrieved February 26, 2017, from http://www.apmex.com/product/102127/atlantic-charter-franklin-d-roosevelt-silver-medal

My Pictures

Atlantic Charter: Franklin D Roosevelt silver medal. (n.d.). Retrieved from http://www.apmex.com/product/102127/atlantic-charter-franklin-d-roosevelt-silver-medal

Franklin D. Roosevelt. (2017). Densho Encyclopedia. Retrieved from http://encyclopedia.densho.org/Franklin_D._Roosevelt/

This coin was made in 1945 to show its commemoration towards President Franklin D. Roosevelt during the Atlantic Charter Franklin D. Roosevelt President from 1933-1945

This artifact is related to cold war tensions.

I chose President Eisenhower and The Interstate Highway System because it was the largest infrastructure project in American history. Additionally, it helped move people to the suburbs in a time when cities were threatened during the heat of the cold war.

I chose this President because I admire him as both a general and a president. Throughout his lifetime he gave his all to protect Americans. Mystery artifact created by,

Sophia Daly

Details:
This is not a remix. The shuttle is made out of metal. steel, and chemicals to fuel the rockets on the bottom. It's unique because it could fit one man and it was the first carrier to allow a man to orbit around Earth.
This is the Friendship 7 capsule, aka Mercury 7 capsule. It was launched on February 20, 1962. It was ordered to go on January 27, 1962.

1. This artifact belongs to NASA
  2. It took off on February 20, 1962, from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station
  3. It carried John Glenn, the first American astronaut to orbit Earth
  4. The project it flew for is named after the first planet in our solar system

The Object:
This is the Mercury 7 aka Friendship 7 capsule.

Details about the Object:
It’s a spacecraft designed to carry one man around the Earth and return safely.

President:
President Kennedy, 1961-1963, Democratic Party

Presidential Role:
Commander-in-Chief

Presidential Act:
President Kennedy gave an executive order to provide funding to help build the spacecraft and to help to program succeed. President Kennedy strongly encouraged the space program, promising to put a man on the moon before 1970. Kennedy got to see the capsule first hand before it took off, and got to talk with and eventually become close friends with John Glenn, who flew the capsule around the Earth.

Impact on America/ Significance:
The Friendship 7 capsule is “the third human spaceflight for the U.S. and part of Project Mercury. Conducted by NASA on February 20, 1962, the mission was piloted by astronaut John Glenn, who performed three orbits of the Earth, making him the first U.S. astronaut to orbit the Earth” (Swenson). This mission helped start the Space Race between the Soviet Union, and because of constant pressure to be better than them, America became a well-respected country after placing a man on the moon.

I chose this President and artifact because I love space, and the idea of putting a man into space and having the President of the United States support science is really fascinating. I believe Kennedy was our greatest president and achieved many great things.

From the object I remixed, I edited the dimensions and added a standing area in the back of the train for people to be outside during their ride, I also added American flags to the top of the train and smoke coming out of the smoke stack.
*These changes did not go through on the printer, but can be seen in the stl file

Clues

Used in the first presidential state trip.

Was used in Panama.

The person using it was overseeing the construction of something.

Significance and Research

The Object:
Train

Details about the Object:
*What are some details about the train itself, what rail road company, what factors differ from what you have and what is in the picture, ie. a railing in the back.
Train used in Panama 1906

President:
Teddy Roosevelt, 1901-1909, Progressive Party

Presidential Role:
Chief Diplomat

Presidential Action:
Teddy Roosevelt was the first president to take a state trip during office. He went to the newly acquired Canal Zone to oversee construction of the Panama Canal. He started the practice of US presidents visiting foreign countries on diplomatic missions.

Impact on America:
**What is the importance of US relationship with Panama, and the significance of the canal?
I chose this president because Theodore Roosevelt was one of the most influential and important presidents in US history. His first state visit started an integral part of foreign policy that is still used today. This train was used by a president of the United States, during the first Presidential visit to another country. This project emphasized this presidents contribution, and made a physical piece of his legacy for others to have. The construction of the Panama canal allowed the United States to develop stronger engineering skills, while also making the United States a formidable military force by having a two-ocean navy.

description.text:
*Fix APA Citation
IS THIS A REMIX?
**More for significance, what is the state of the Cherokee now? What challenges do they still face?

Mystery Artifact Created by: Karla Hernandez

Clues:

“The symbol on the hat is of the Cherokee tribe”
“The hat doesn’t belong to the president itself, but to someone (not part of the U.S. government) who also had much influence on a large group of people”
“He indirectly killed many Natives”
“This president created his own political party”

Questions
Which president do you think this object is connected to?
Why is he so significant in U.S. History?
What was the cause of so many deaths in the Native American population?

The Object:
A Top Hat

Details about the Object:
The symbol of the Cherokee tribe is to connect the hat with John Ross. He was the leader of the Cherokee tribe during the Jackson Administration.

President:
Andrew Jackson, Democrat, March 4, 1829 – March 4, 1837

Presidential Role
Chief Legislator

Political Action:
The Indian Removal Act of 1830
“The Indian Removal Act was signed into law by President Andrew Jackson on May 28, 1830, authorizing the president to grant unsettled lands west of the Mississippi in exchange for Indian lands within existing state borders. A few tribes went peacefully, but many resisted the relocation policy.” (loc.gov)

Impact on America/ Significance
I decided to research this president because of how radical his views and actions were. He greatly impacted the Native Americans; it is seen through America’s westward expansion in the belief of Manifest Destiny and how Natives now live in reservation sites throughout the country.

Mystery artifact created by,
Vivek Rao

clues

My object is a reference to the 1994 NATO summit in Dinant Brussels. The object is a gift given to a certain Head of State for a particular western country. The object is an instrument. The instrument is a rare original instrument from the inventor of this particular instrument. During this summit a treaty was signed regarding security interests in Europe. The inventor of the instrument given to Clinton was from Brussels.

Significance & Research (w/ citations)

The Object:
A original Adolphe Sax saxophone from Dinant Belgium. Bill Clinton received this saxophone from the mayor of Dinant; Dinant is the hometown of Adolphe Sax. Adolphe Sax invented the saxophone. This item was gifted to Clinton in 1994 after he revealed the partnership for peace initiative. The Gift represents approval for his plan, because the gift is from the NATO country of Brussels (usnews.com).

Details about the Object:

  1. A original Adolphe Sax saxophone from Dinant Belgium. He received this saxophone from the mayor of Dinant; Dinant is the hometown of Adolphe Sax. Adolphe Sax invented the saxophone. This item was gifted to Clinton in 1994 after he revealed the partnership for peace initiative. The Gift represents approval for his plan, because the gift is from the NATO country of Brussels (usnews.com).
  2. I have found many photographs of this object with my President (usnews.com).
  3. This object can be displayed in a museum. Many of Adolphe inventions including his Saxophone were honored recently (forbes.com).
    1. This object is extremely valuable. It is a relic from a historic event. The announcement of the Partnership for Peace initiative was a historic event (Miller Center). Items from historical events are valuable
      President:
      President: Bill Clinton President # 42(Miller Center). He contributed to the Partnership for Peace and, announced that the United States would maintain about 100,000 troops in Europe (Miller Center).

Contribution/The Act & Presidential Role.
This relates to the Presidential role of Chief Diplomat. The President is managing the United States foreign policy. He is acting as the chief diplomat, because he is representing the entire United States on Foreign Policy.
Impact on America/Significance
The president at the 1994 NATO Summit in Brussels, Belgium He announced the Partnership for Peace program. This program lead by the United States aimed to foster better relations between European Countries and Warsaw Pact countries. He also committed 100,000 U.S. soldiers to Europe (Miller Center).

I chose Bill Clinton and the presidential power I chose to exemplify is chief diplomat. I chose Clinton, because I feel he was a very successful president that had his legacy tarnished from personal issues.

(pmwoodwind.com).
(usnews.com).

title: "Ugly" Stick plane (works with my 1133mm wing Design)

description.text:
NEW Complete Aircraft https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2337232

This is my version of the classic "ugly" stick RC planes.
This plane uses the wing I designed and previously posted as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2078106

I have NOT printed the complete aircraft at this time, only test prints.

I set it to print at 100% infill, one perimeter (2 perimeters may print better), 2 top & bottom layers & with supports for the main fuselage parts. The flat tail surfaces (elevator & rudder components) and the hatch doors should print well with 50 to 75% honeycomb infill (possibly less). These settings seem to work well with a .35mm tip on my prusa I3 with PLA.

Assembly is done using 10 - 25mm long 2mm joiner pins and is glued using medium CA glue
The control surfaces on the tail are hinged using starndard CA hinged. The elevator sections are joined with 2mm pins and CA glue. The hatch (nose) and battery door are hinged simply with tape or can be hinged using Dubro hidden hinges.
This plane is designed to use this motor https://hobbyking.com/en_us/d2826-6-2200kv-outrunner-motor.html or similar with a 7X5 prop, a 35A or better esc, and a 2200 to 2800mAh 3cell 30C battery. Servos used are Tower Pro MG90S

title: Boeing 737 Headset Hook
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I kept my nice €1000 headset on my flight bag when not in use during ground turnarounds and after just two months it died because it had some strain on the cables when it was on top of the bag.

So i made this neat little hook. It snaps onto the sunshade rail and you can of course still open the DV window should you need to shout at the fueler :) Fits on both sides.

If your are printing with a stiff material like PLA, choose the "stiff materials" version. If you are printing with something more flexible like ColorFabb HT, choose the "flexible materials" version. The flexible materials version is a little thicker around the rail joint to prevent it from popping off too easily.

Disclaimer: This is not approved by anyone for anything. Use at your own risk!

description.text: There are two types of members, a 1inch member and a 1.4 inch member. There are individual stls for both members. In addition there is an stl with all 1.4 inch members and one stl with all 1 inch members required for the bridge. Both member types were printed at 100% infill. In total it weighs about 26.5 grams and can hold about 9.7kg. This means that the bridge has about a 366 load to weight ratio.

title: CNC Base for ANOTHER Machine Vise

description.text:
This is a variation of my OTHER Machine vise. Modified base halves for Nema 14 mount. Includes also a modified Center Gear. The remaining parts (sliding jaw, jaw plates, threaded rods, threaded gears, pins) are from the original vise.

It also works with the modified threaded rods: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2123529. Since their pitch is 4mm and the regular rods have 1.75mm pitch, the clamping force will be less, but the jaw will move faster. The clamping force also depends on the current from the stepper driver.

comments.author: mrpaine

description.text:
Measurements have been slightly modified to compensate shrinking of ABS after printing.
Nozzle delta is X+/- 14mm relative to X0/Y0 of original extruder mounting plate. Version "V2_mod" aka "old Skully" has X +/- 13mm and greater notches for the heater- and thermistor wires. Version "V3" aka "crimson hun" has also X +/- 13mm. It includes a cooling solution for the PEEK. I tried it successfully with one single 25x20mm high-power fan. With 25x10mm models, you should use two of them. This version is quiet good to print. I printet it with a .35mm nozzle at .15mm layer height using black ABS.
"V3" requires the "Spacer_New_V3".
Edit: .STL File updated - Slic3r had some issues with the old version. Version "V4" aka "why-didn't-I-think-about-this-earlier" has the spacers included. This is the Version I actually use here (with two 25x20mm fans). Note: I had to make some changes to the Repetier FW (0.83) in order to use one fan output (FAN2) for cooling the PEEKs, wether heater 1 or heater 2 (or both) is in use. One issue that will occure is the "swiveling" of the effector plate while moving from the center of the bed to the outer areas. This is no problem with one extruder (centric mounted). With two extruders and the relative delta-x, it is a real challange to get rid of the ever changing Z-alingnment. I minimized this effect by tweaking the "END_EFFECTOR_HORIZONTAL_OFFSET" definition in Repetier's configuration. Just play around with it and watch what happens. Maybe a "V5" with a 40mm fan mount/duct for cooling PLA prints will follow soon. :-)

I recommend printing with ABS. I print at .15 layer height and with reduced speed.
After the printing you may have to sand the spacers a little bit in order to make them the same height. The amount of sanding depends much on your printer's calibration and on the material you have used. The holes for the Extruders should be tight fitting. If there is play, wrap aluminIum foil arround the extruders. Sand the main hole of the effector plate in order to gain some space between the extruder hot end and the effector material. Else you may just burn it away. About 4 mm of space is ok. I used a 10 mm hobbing cutter and a dremel. Plug in the hot ends in the mount you had carefully sanded before.
Adjust the vertical alignment with shims of aliminium foil. Then put the ends out again. Now assemble the fans to the mount. I did this using M2 x 30 mm screws and self-locking nuts. Screw the mount to the effector, dont tighten the srcrews at this time, then (!) put in the hot ends and don't forget your shims. You see, there's not much space for getting the hot ends in. The cables of the thermistors and the heating cartridges should be fixed with zip ties on the elongated hole in the middle. Same for the wires of the fan(s). Another method for vertical aligning the hot ends is using heat resistant rubber-made edge protectors. Put them between the hot end stop-plate and the mount. The squeeze together when you tighten the screws of the hot ends, yet they are stiff enough to provide a stable hold. If you have found a better way (and surely there are better ways :-) ) for installing the SmCNC hot ends, let me know.

comments.text: Oh... So the V2 hasn't the mounting holes on the lower top plate anymore? Because, judging from the pictures on SMCNC website, it should be the same plate/layout as the one on the V1. Only the upper plate is new. I have an V1, so I can only guess.

Worked great! Printed mine in nylon and didn't even need shims to be eyeball-level. I could improve it with more careful leveling I'm sure and a bit of fine tuning of the separation parameter in the firmware, but my first dual head print (when I got the firmware changes correct) was a total success! I double-stacked my 25mm fans on the same output and it prints PLA pretty well. I need to revisit my filament-fan mounting and firmware options though, my PEEK fans are stuck at 100% and the filament fan is not close enough to the filament to matter using the stock (well, recommended) fan. Only lost 8.7mm of height, which was nice. (I printed V4.)

comments.author: JolietDelta

comments.text:
Basically by setting the Fallback-Speed from "0" to "250" (idle speed). Further I'm saving each heater's status in a global Var. With this setup I can turn on my main PEEK fan everytime when one of the both heaters is above 40C. Below 40C I'm running in idle mode (PWM 250).
As this is a mean hack, I don't dare to post it here. Without further modifications you can potentially nuke your PEEK. I'm going to make a code-push to repetier. Maybe this kind of cooling behaviour is worth an #IFDEF section in the main source fork. If not, I'm going to re-work that routine a bit, so that the implementation is more safe for unexperienced users.

comments.text: I'm still a novice, but would do the following.
comments.author: JolietDelta

comments.text:
Well, you're free to map like you want to map. :-) The reasons why I made it this way are:
It is unlikely that one (me) wants to have two fans for every single extruder, as the airflows would mix together after the duct anyway. Only one extruder is in use at a time, so the cooling strategy for the filament can be performed by only one fan.

An airplane I made in 2006. It is not supposed to be based in any existing plain, just a generic plane y imagined.

I present here our design of gimbal rotary of 2 models for gimbal 2 axes and 3 axes

2-axis model uses DYS brand motors
3-axis model uses 3-axis gimbal storm32 motors

This model has been completely redesigned, with reinforcements implemented, and realized for cameras Sj4000, xioami yi, vamso to make later models for cameras Gpro, Firefly 6s etc

We have worked with ABS and PLA models the result in ABS is very amazing after going through acetone, PLA is a little harder to leave smooth, but if you work with PLA down to 0.1mm of line separation, also with 25% Of filling is sufficient, but we have tried with 25% and 50% of filling.

The most sensitive part is where the anti-vibration gums are placed, but with care will not have problem

This gimbal is self-locking and blocks with just turn as the original of inspired 1, hemso tried similar to the original, with a central ajugero to pass the wires, this gimbal is very good for many drones which we encesitas a lace and rapid disembedding of the gimbal , As inspired or similar.

title: Wall holder for Alfa USB adapters with high gain antenna

description.text:
I needed to use some Alfa USB adapters with high gain antenna for some wifi work. To keep the adapter and antenna in place I designed this wall holder.

Screw the screws tight when this holder is placed on the wall. The adapter might be hard to get out of the holder again if the screws are sticking to much up. If I am going to make more of this, I might make the backside thicker so that I can 'embed' the screw head in the backside. It's done in the file: "Alfa USB adapter holder v0_3.fcstd"

I made the model in FreeCAD, www.freecadweb.org, converted the finished part into a mesh object and exported it out as a stl file. I used the recommended settings for the slicer for my printer. Printed it with ABS.

The FreeCAD files are included if you would like to alter anything. The stl files are also included.

And, well it works as intended.

description.text:
I wanted a camera on the print bed of my Malyan M150 because with both the bed and the hot end moving, remote monitoring and the timelapse videos just tended to become a mush of moving parts. No reason why you can't use this on any other printer.

With the camera mounted to the bed, the only moving part in video is the print head.

For this camera mount, you will need to remove the heated bed (and probably the Y carriage plate in order to drill it. I tried other mounts but without a firm fixing to the bed, found that the camera vibrated leading to blurred video.

Measure the offset carefully as this mounts with 3mm screws and you need to make sure that with the bed fully forward, that the screws/nuts don't foul the chassis of the printer at the front.

The camera swivel came from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1258498 but I just included the part here to save you hunting for it separately.

I have also included an earlier mount that I used which does not require taking the LifeCam apart to change the bracket. Google on how to take it apart, it's not difficult, just a bit fiddly.

Printer:

Malyan M150

0.2

whatever you fancy

Notes:

I printed mine in ABS because I found that in an enclosure, other parts that were PLA (and even PETG) sagged.

If you're not printing ABS and have no requirement for heat resistance, PLA or PETG will be fine.

title: Muscular Dystrophy Flat Spoon
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I made this spoon for Elsha, with measurements she gave me. She suffers from muscular dystrophy since her birth and reached out for help via our forums (http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/things-with-actual-uses/topic:11607#comment-1236363). The disease degenerates a patients muscles over time, Elsha has this disease since her birth.

She is doing a lot of artwork with only her head(https://www.facebook.com/u2elshanator). When I first got her spoon measurements I thought someone was making fun of me, but Elsha reached out for me via Facebook where I saw pictures of her and then everything made sense to me.

This is the printed prototypes, luckily I recently got a Form2 to print this delicate design.
Here is a video of the spoon https://youtu.be/Ae80t6pXSvo
The foto shows a metric scale, the print process and the post-curing.
This video shows the print process https://youtu.be/bqJ4-MfYMfU.

Check out the below sections for important info on food safety!

Printer:

Form2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Highest Quality

Infill:

-

Notes:

Orienting the spoon slightly sideways at about 40 degrees and then letting Preform create supports.

Have to still test if there is a better orientation.

The clear Resin I used in printing the spoon is not food safe! See info in summary to make sure not to misuse 3DPrinting for objects that get into contact with food or your mouth.
As always I used Cinema 4D as the tool of choice. I used hypernurbs with a low poly version of the spoon, to keep it easily adjustable to Elsha's needs.
Important info on food safety and 3DPrinting: Use 3D Printed objects on your own risk and get yourself informed well, not all materials are safe and not all production processes are safe

comments.author: starkejustin

comments.text:
here's what I did:
I made a slab of the general shape that I wanted the outside to be, using minkowski function to round corners and intersecting it with various large cylinders to get the proper shape on the outside. that was the easy part since I could make it whatever shape took my fancy.
Next I made some very careful measurments. I even traced the outline of my phone and held it up to the screen to verify the outline. I also used the minkowski function and intersection using large cylinders to get the proper curve. I never had a digital model to work from so I used my own phone and adjusted the shape as I described always starting from a slab-like starting shape. then, when I had what I believed was a shape that was suitable I used the difference function to subtract it from the outside slab I had started with. to make the top open so i could insert a phone, I designed a series of rectangular prizms and elipses subtracted them all from the final product.to allow different plugs and speakers to be exposed for easy access. there were some trial and error prints where I adjusted it before the final product. it wasn't perfect but it works pretty well.

title: RC Plane landing gear offset/extension (for skis/floats)

description.text:
These offsets / extensions are designed for use with the skis http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1223555, but can be used with wheels and floats as well.
They attach by sliding over the existing wheel mount, then using a 1.5mm screw (servo mount screw) to lock in place, a 3mm bolt is then used to mount the ski / wheel / float. These extensions make swapping between skis and wheels quick and easy, 1 screw to take them on and off, I leave them permanently mounted to the skis.
There are holes integrated in for use with the springs required for skis.

These will print best at 100% infill, 3 perimeters, 3 top & bottom layers & with supports. These settings seem to work well with a .35mm tip on my prusa I3 with PLA, ABS or ASA.
After printing the holes will most likely need to be drilled out. I have included my original 123D Design files for use if modifications are needed, these scale very nicely if required.

description.text:
NOW LIVE ON KICKSTARTER https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1346069182/plexibots?ref=nav_search Timing Belt Pulleys
Included are a 20 tooth 6mm pulley for a GT2 belt and a 36 tooth 6mm pulley for a GT2 belt. These are the commonly used pulleys for 3D printers.
Our pulleys directly accomodate a chamfered 5mm shaft as included in all NEMA 17 motors. We have hacked the following OpenCad script --
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16627
We thus have the capability of generating the design for many different belt types, belt widths and number of teeth. If you would like to see any additional timing belt pulleys, please contact us.
Use our joining and angle plates for idler pulleys.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213776
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213750
We also have a set of complementary gears.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:214043
NOTES:
We are planning to get many of these parts molded so "makers" can buy em cheap and use for their projects. We need your feedback --
What other parts would you like added to the library?
What colors should different parts be molded in?
What would you build with it?
Would you like any parts modified?
We welcome other comments and suggestions

message = Happy 2014 Elite Imageworks
hi

There is one Arduino R3 variant I could not get any case for: It's called a RobotDyn Uno. This is an el cheapo knockoff of an Arduino R3 I got from Aliexpress. This variant comes with a nice twist: Analog lines A6 and A7 (usually there is only A0 to A5) are provided on a seperate header between ICSP and Analog header. Unfortunately, the result of this is that none of the regular Arduino cases would fit since there is no hole in the top for that header.
Esquilo did a nice job with his snug case, so I use this to do a quick mod in order to fit this Arduino variant.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Top plate should be printed face down.
One should avoid printing this in PLA since the noses holding down the top are VERY easy to break off. Better use PETG or ABS
